children.name: criticize
children.definition: /criticiseUK  to express your disapproval of someone or something, or to talk about their faultsOPP praise: phê phán chỉ trích
examples: Ron does nothing but criticize and complain all the time.

children.name: strongly/severely/heavily criticize somebody/something
examples: Public transport has been severely criticized in the report.

children.name: sharply/harshly/fiercely criticize somebody/something
children.definition: in an angry way
examples: His attorney sharply criticized the police yesterday.

children.name: be widely criticized
examples: The proposal was widely criticized.

children.name: publicly criticize somebody/something
examples: The head coach publicly criticized the referee’s decision.

children.name: roundly criticize somebody/something
children.definition: strongly and severely
examples: Their research has been roundly criticized.

children.name: openly criticize somebody/something
children.definition: in a public and direct way
examples: They openly criticized the government’s handling of the crisis.

children.name: repeatedly/frequently/constantly criticize
examples: The fashion industry is frequently criticized for presenting extremely thin models as beautiful.

children.name: be quick to criticize sb/sth
examples: Some groups were quick to criticize the President.

children.name: criticize sb/sth on the grounds that
children.definition: for the reason that
examples: The survey was criticized on the grounds that the sample was too small.

children.name: be strongly/sharply/heavily criticized
examples: The decision has been strongly criticized by teachers.
The new law has beenwidely criticized.

children.name: criticize sb/sth for (doing) sth
examples: He has been criticized for incompetence.
Doctors have criticized the government for failing to invest enough in the health service.

children.name: criticize sb/sth as sth
examples: The report has been criticized as inaccurate and incomplete.

children.name: be critical
children.definition: to strongly criticize a plan, system, or way of doing sth, especially when you givedetailedreasonswhy you think it is wrong: chỉ trích , chê bai
examples: Don’t be so critical - we’re doing our best.

children.name: be critical of
examples: Miller was critical of the way the company was managed.
Many economists are critical of the government’s economic policies.

children.name: be highly/ strongly criticalvery critical
examples: Environmental groups were highly critical of the government’s new transportation policy.
Many parents are strongly critical of the school.
He made some highly critical remarks.

children.name: be a critic of
children.definition: sb/sth if sb is a critic of the government, a person in authority etc, they regularly and publicly criticize them, especially by giving detailed reasons for this: là nhà phê bình ai đó/cái gì đó
examples: ▪ She is one of the most well-known critics of the American private school system.

children.name: be an outspoken critic of sb/sthnot afraid to critize strongly and publicly
examples: ▪ He is regarded as one of Congress’s most outspoken critics of television violence.

children.name: be somebody’s greatest/biggest etccritic criticize them more than anyone else does
examples: ▪ Mr Levy has established a reputation as the committee’s biggest, most vehement critic.

children.name: sth you say or write to criticize
criticism
children.definition: what you say or write when you criticize sb or sthOPP praise: sự phê bình chỉ trích, lời bình phẩm trỉ trích
examples: Bill’s very sensitive to any kind of criticism.

children.name: strong/severe/heavy criticism
examples: This decision attracted heavy criticism from environmental groups.

children.name: fierce/bitter/harsh/sharp criticism
children.definition: involving angry feelings
examples: The prison system has been the object of fierce criticism.

children.name: public criticism
examples: As a politician, you have to get used to public criticism.

children.name: constructive criticism
children.definition: aimed at improving something or someone in a helpful way
examples: Praise and constructive criticism are both very useful.

children.name: widespread criticism
examples: There was widespread criticism of his speech.

children.name: growing/mounting criticism
examples: The government was faced with mounting criticism at home and abroad.

children.name: outspoken criticism
children.definition: said very openly and directly
examples: I was surprised by his outspoken criticism of the system.

children.name: implied criticism
children.definition: suggested indirectly, rather than said openly
examples: She sensed the implied criticism in his remarks.

children.name: draw/attract/provoke criticism
children.definition: be criticized
examples: The plan has drawn criticism from some groups.

children.name: come under criticism/come in for criticism
children.definition: be criticized
examples: The deal came under fierce criticism from other American airlines.

children.name: meet
children.definition: with
examples: criticism(= be criticized )His theory met with harsh criticism from colleagues.

children.name: face criticism
examples: He has often faced criticism in the local press.

children.name: accept/take criticism
children.definition: allow it and learn from it
examples: Very few people know how to accept criticism.

children.name: level criticism at somebody/something
children.definition: aim it at someone or something
examples: A great deal of criticism was levelled at the company.

children.name: single somebody out for criticism
children.definition: to criticize one person, organization etc specifically
examples: The goalkeeper was singled out for criticism.

children.name: be the subject of criticism/be subjected to criticism
children.definition: be criticized by people
examples: The club has been the subject of criticism since last October.

children.name: be open to criticism
children.definition: be willing or able to accept it
examples: Management have decided this and I don't think they're open to criticism.

children.name: be sensitive to criticism
children.definition: to react to criticism, often in a bad way
examples: He was highly sensitive to criticism in the press.

children.name: a storm/barrage of criticism
children.definition: a lot of criticism
examples: His comments provoked a barrage of criticism.

children.name: criticism of
examples: The report makes many criticisms of the nation’s prison system.
My main criticism of the scheme is that it does nothing to help families on low incomes.

children.name: attack
children.definition: a statement that criticizes sb publicly, especially in politics or business: công kích , trỉ trích

children.name: attack on
examples: The magazine recently published a viciouspersonal attackon the novelist.
O'Brien promised to continue his attacks on the film industry.

children.name: come under attackbe criticized by sb
examples: Once again the oil companies have come under attack from environmentalists.
The company has come under fierce attack for its decision to close the factory.

children.name: launch an attack
examples: France launched a bitter attack on EU proposals to reduce farm subsidies.

children.name: go on the attack(= start to criticize sb severely )
slur
children.definition: an unfair criticism that is intended to make people dislike sb or sth: gièm pha, nói xấu,
examples: Your accusation of bribe-taking is a slur which I shall never forgive.
a racist slur
slur on/against
Milton regarded her comment as a slur on his country.
How dare shecastaslur on(= criticize )my character?

children.name: put-down
children.definition: sth that sb says to sb, especially when other people are there, that criticizes them and makes them feel stupid or unimportant: làm nhục, làm bẽ mặt

children.name: ▪ She was a master of the sarcastic put-down
examples: .▪ I didn’t mean it as a put-down but I could tell from her response that she took my criticism personally.

children.name: critic
children.definition: sb who criticizes sb or sth especially in public: người trỉ trích
examples: The Prime Minister answered his critics in a televised speech.
critic of
Daley accused critics of the city’s Police Department of lying.
Critics of the scheme have said that it will not solve the problem of teenage crime.
fierce/outspoken critic
an outspoken critic of the government

children.name: find fault with
children.definition: to criticize things that are wrong with someone or something, especiallysmallandunimportantthings: bắt bẻ, kiếm truyện
examples: No-one enjoys working for a boss who always finds fault with their work.

children.name: find fault with sb for sth
examples: The report found fault with the police department for its handling of the case.

children.name: pick holes in
children.definition: especially British,informalto criticizesmalldetails in someone’s ideas or plans - use this about someone who seems to bedeliberatelylooking for problems and mistakes: tìm ra được lỗ hổng, đào bới
examples: As soon as she stopped talking, Janet’s colleagues began to pick holes in the idea.

children.name: knock
children.definition: to criticize sb, their work, or their performance in an unfair and annoying way: chỉ trích gay gắt, phê bình kịch liệt, “đánh đập”
examples: It’s hard to knock Gordon because he always works so hard.
Critics knocked his latest film for its portrayal of women.
don’t knock it!
Hey, don’t knock it! It’s the only suit I’ve got!

children.name: put down U
children.definition: put down to make sb feel unimportant or stupid especially by criticizing them in public: làm bẽ mặt, làm nhục
examples: Television programs always seem to put down people from the South.
She enjoys putting me down in front of other people.

children.name: slag off
children.definition: UK informal to criticize sb, especially in a nasty and unfair way: vu khống, phỉ báng
examples: She spent the whole evening slagging off her ex-boyfriend.
When the team isn’t winning everyone starts slagging them off.
He’s always slagging you off behind your back.

children.name: bitch about
children.definition: sb informal to make nasty remarks about sb when that person is not there: nói xấu, vu khống
examples: People in our office are always bitching about each other.

children.name: get at
children.definition: sb informal to keep criticizing sb by making remarks about their behaviour or habits, especially in an unkind or annoying way: chế nhạo, giễu cợt
examples: ▪ I try not to take it personally -- he gets at everyone on the team.

children.name: get at sb about
examples: ▪ My mother keeps getting at me about the state of my room.

children.name: nitpicking
children.definition: the annoying habit of criticizing sb about unimportant details, especially in sb’s work: soi mói, bới lông tìm vết
examples: I’ve had enough of your constant nit-picking. Why can’t you say something encouraging?
nitpicking[attri]
nitpicking remarks

children.name: scathing
children.definition: criticizing sb or sth verystrongly, because you think they are completelywrongor of verylowquality: cay độc , gay gắt
examples: scathing attack/remark/comment etc
a scathing attack on the government’s planned tax increases
Her new book is a scathing attack on American imperialism in Central America.
The health department issued a scathing report on conditions in local hospitals.
scathing about
‘The New York Times’ was particularly scathing about his performance.
He’s always been so scathing about psychiatrists.

children.name: pejorative
children.definition: a pejorative word expresses disapproval, often in an offensive way: miệt thị
examples: He used the word ‘girl’ in the pejorative sense when referring to the women who worked for him.
For hard-line Republicans, the word ‘liberal’ had become a pejorative term.

children.name: derogatory
children.definition: a derogatory remark expresses disapproval of sth or sb and is often also insulting: xúc phạm, hạ thấp người khác
examples: I wish you wouldn’t make derogatory remarks about members of my family.
I didn’t like the way he made derogatory comments about his colleagues.

children.name: critical
children.definition: a critical statement, report, or description criticizes someone or something: chỉ trích, chê bai
examples: ▪ Critical remarks by a teacher can damage the confidence of children.

children.name: highly criticalvery critical
examples: ▪ The government has just published a highly critical report on the state of the education system.

children.name: negative
children.definition: a negative comment, report etc is intended to criticize someone or something, especially in a way that is unnecessary or unfair; a negative person has a tendency to criticize or complain about everything, especially when this is annoying or unfair: tiêu cực
examples: ▪ The portrayal of working women in the media tends to be very negative.
▪ You shouldn’t let his negative comments get you down - he doesn’t know what he’s talking about.
▪ I wish you’d stop being so negative all the time!

children.name: attack
children.definition: to criticize sb or sth very strongly, especially publicly in the newspapers, on TV etc: chỉ trích , phê phán , tấn công
examples: ▪ Several actors have attacked proposals to cut the theatre’s budget.

children.name: attack sb for (doing) sth
examples: ▪ Union leaders attacked management for eliminating employee health benefits.

children.name: slam
children.definition: to criticize sb or sth very strongly in a public statement -- used especially in newspapers: đả kích, "đóng sầm"
examples: ▪ Sullivan never misses a chance to slam the tobacco industry.
slam sb for doing sth
▪ Police slammed drivers for ignoring safety warnings

children.name: pan
children.definition: to strongly criticize sth such as a film, play, or a performance by writing about it in a newspaper, talking about it on television etc: chỉ trích gay gắt
examples: The movie was panned by all the critics.
Her first movie was panned by the critics.

children.name: tear sb to shreds
children.definition: tear sb/sth to shreds to find a lot of faults in sb’s ideas or arguments and criticize them very severely: đả kích tơi tả
examples: The prosecution will tear him to shreds.
After the prosecutor had presented his case, the defence lawyer tore his arguments to shreds.

children.name: pillory
children.definition: bêu rếu, “đem gông, bỏ gông”
examples: be pilloriedespecially writtento be strongly criticized by a lot of people in the newspapers, on TV etc :
He was pilloried in the right-wing press.
Harper was pilloried in the press after his team’s sixth consecutive defeat.
Middleton suffered the ultimate humiliation of being pilloried by his colleagues in front of the television cameras.

children.name: do a hatchet job on
children.definition: to criticize every part of sb’s character or work: bôi nhọ, bêu rếu, “cái rìu nhỏ”
examples: ▪ Field did a complete hatchet job on his former colleague at a cabinet meeting last week.

children.name: lay into
children.definition: sb/tear intosb informal to criticize sb very strongly for sth they have done,especially by shouting at them: quở trách, chỉ trích, đánh tới tấp
examples: The teacher really laid into us this morning - told us we’d all fail if we didn’t start doing some work.
He started laying into one of his staff for being late.

children.name: lay into about
examples: You should have heard my wife laying into me about coming home late last night.

children.name: come in for criticism
children.definition: bị chỉ trích
examples: The unions came in for strong criticism from the government after the strike.
Caro came in for a lot of criticism for his biography of the late president.
The director has come in for a lot of criticism over his handling of the affair.

children.name: be under attack
children.definition: /fire to be severely criticized, especially in public: bị chỉ trích, bị bêu rếu
examples: Banks are under attack for their refusal to reduce interest rates on loans to small businesses.

children.name: come under attack/fire
examples: His theories came under attack from other scientists.
The police department has come under fire for the recent rise in violent crime.

children.name: take a lot of flak
children.definition: get/ informal to be criticized a lot for sth: “hỏa lực phòng không” bị la mắng, bị đả kích
examples: Ferguson been getting a lot of flak for the team’s poor performance recently.
The immigration department is taking a lot of political flak for not moving faster to help the refugees.
Lilley hastakena lot offlakfor his views on drugs.

children.name: be open to criticism
children.definition: if sb or sth is open to criticism, there are good reasons for criticizing them: có thể bị chỉ trích
examples: The general is open to criticism for his handling of the war.
Current reforms in the legal system may be open to criticism if they appear to be undemocratic.

children.name: be in the firing line
children.definition: UK/ on the firing lineUS  likely to be criticized for sth, even if you are not the only person who is responsible for it: đứng mũi chịu sào
examples: As head of the police department, Hall is constantly on the firing line.
When you’re in the firing line, it’s tempting to avoid making difficult decisions.

children.name: target
children.definition: an organization, person in authority etc that is criticized, especially by a lot of people: mục tiêu chỉ trích

children.name: target of
examples: Kay was the target of a noisy demonstration in which 54 people were arrested.

children.name: target for
examples: The Communist Party has become the main target for critical attack among left-wing intellectuals.
